title: Soapwatch: JACI STEPHEN'S ultimate insight into this week's soaps
text:
There is nothing more boring than a drugs-related storyline because there can only ever be two outcomes: the character keeps taking them and something horrible happens, or they stop and get their life together.

But when they are in the throes of the addiction, they relate to everyone and everything around them in a one-dimensional way – i.e. not very nice.

Emmerdale’s had more than its fair share of drug plots and now Corrie and EastEnders are on the bandwagon again, with Ali and Rainie both hooked on painkillers.

Secretly hiding the problem while claiming to be clean, both have descended into unsociable animals who care only about where their next fix is coming from.

We’ve been down this path with Rainie before (and it was just as boring then, even with co-dependent Phil self-combusting before our eyes), but Ali seemed to turn druggie overnight.

Maybe it was through the stress of dating Maria, or maybe the culprit is all those long days at the pub… I mean the hospital.

Yes, it’s a serious issue. But dramatically, the stories feel like a drug to cure insomnia.

CORONATION STREET

TEARS FOR FEARS

Sinead Tinker (Katie McGlynn) fights back tears as she breaks the news to family and friends that she only has weeks to live. Pictured, with Daniel (Rob Mallard)

You’d have to have a heart of stone not to be moved by Sinead’s struggle, and despite agreeing with Daniel to savour every day, she receives more bad news when the oncologist says she has just weeks to live.

It’s just not what you want to hear at any time, let alone when you have to attend Ken’s 80th.

And it gets worse, when Daniel reveals that he and Beth have also made it a surprise party for Bertie’s first birthday (don’t these people watch EastEnders and the horrors of every surprise party since time began?).

LEAST LIKELY OUTCOME ‘I just want you to be ’appy.’ Robert to Michelle, Corrie

Fighting back tears at Bertie’s bash in the back yard (inset), Sinead publicly announces her imminent demise.

Back at the flat, she expresses regret at having to leave Daniel, although secure in the knowledge Bertie will be in safe hands.

Seriously, stock up on the Kleenex; both performances (Katie McGlynn and Rob Mallard) will have you drowning in tears.

Actually, forget the Kleenex; start lining up the buckets.

In other news, following their break-up, Ali looks on jealously as Gary flirts with Maria.

Talk about frying pan to fire, Maria.

Why not just barbecue yourself right now and have done with the middle man?

EASTENDERS

BEDSIDE MANNERS

Sonia (Natalie Cassidy), seated centre, accuses Martin (James Bye), right, of not being there for Bex (Jasmin Armfield), in bed, as they gather by her bedside in EastEnders

With Bex in hospital, will this be the moment everyone realises that springing a surprise send-off is always going to end in tears? In fact, the only pleasant surprise with them is if someone does not end up dead/unconscious/choking on one of Ian’s vol-au-vents.

Oblivious to what has happened between Martin and the Mitchells, Sonia takes the opportunity of her ex’s presence at Bex’s bedside to accuse him of not being there for his daughter.

QUESTION OF THE DECADE ‘What’s the story with you and Ally McBeal?’ Debbie to Sophie, Corrie

Hang on – this from the woman who put Bex up for adoption, has enjoyed stints as both a man- and woman-eater and was arrested for the murder of Pauline.

I’d say Martin has a veritable clingfilm of a relationship with Bex among that lot.

Feeling guilty (that’s a first), Sonia begs Martin to stay and he and Bex return to the Square to have a heart to heart.

Now if there’s one thing more doomed than a surprise party, it’s an East End ’eart to ’eart.

Sure enough, within minutes, Martin and Ben spot each other across the Square.

Think Djokovic and Nadal on opposite sides of the net; Spassky and Fischer on opposite sides of a chessboard.

On second thoughts, think Beavis and Butt-Head.

The two are forced to join forces when Jags reveals he’s kidnapped Lola (who’s minding Martin’s stall during all this, by the way?), but tensions again reach breaking point when Ben reneges on a promise.

Yer don’t say.

EMMERDALE: FAKE IT TO MAKE IT

Mandy (Lisa Riley), pictured, pretends to be Lydia Hart in the hopes of getting money from a mysterious solicitor in Emmerdale

Does losing weight make you selfish? Each time Mandy returns, slimmer and more glamorous, she’s more of a Mean Girl than the time before.

When a mysterious solicitor (is there any other kind? This one looks like Don Corleone’s lawyer) turns up at Wishing Well, he tells Mandy that Lydia Hart has been gifted a large sum of money.

Mandy wastes no time in pretending to be Lydia as she tries to persuade Mr Dodgy to hand over the dosh.

Will she feel guilty when Lydia and Sam arrive? She needs to lay off the lettuce and recapture the cuddly part of her soul.

Barry Manilow’s Mandy, she ain’t.
description: In this week's Coronation Street, Sinead publicly announces that she has just weeks to live. Meanwhile in EastEnders, Sonia accuses Martin of not being there for his daughter.
authors: Jaci Stephen For The Daily Mail
